perturbation.original_text: This Unconditional Capital Maintenance Agreement (this "Agreement"), is made, entered into and effective as of March 30, 2011, by and between American International Group, Inc., a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Delaware ("AIG"), and American General Life Insurance Company of Delaware, a corporation organized under the laws of the Delaware (the "Company").
perturbation.changed_text: This Unconditional Capital Maintenance Agreement (this "Agreement"), is made, entered into and effective as of March 30, 2011, by and between American International Group, Inc., a corporation organized under the laws of the State of Delaware ("AIG"), and American General Life Insurance Company of Delaware, a corporation organized under the laws of the Delaware (the "Insurer").
perturbation.explanation: Changing the term "Company" to "Insurer" introduces ambiguity. While the context suggests they refer to the same entity, this is not explicitly defined, and later uses of "Company" may create confusion about which entity is being referenced.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that the Company's Total Adjusted Capital for each of the        Company's first and third fiscal quarters (as determined based on the        Company's first and third fiscal quarterly filed statutory financial        statements, respectively, subject to any adjustments or modifications        thereto required by the Domiciliary State's insurance department or the        Company's independent auditors) falls below the Specified Minimum        Percentage of the Company's projected Company Action Level RBC (in each        case as estimated by the Company as of the end of each such first and        third fiscal quarters, as the case may be), AIG shall, within the        respective time periods set forth under paragraph 4, in accordance with        paragraph 5 and in compliance with applicable law, provide to the        Company cash, cash equivalents, securities or other instruments that        qualify (as admitted assets) for purposes of calculating the Company's        Total Adjusted Capital, as a contribution and not as a loan, in an        amount such that the Company's Total Adjusted Capital as of the end of        each of the
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that the Insurer's Total Adjusted Capital for each of the        Company's first and third fiscal quarters (as determined based on the        Company's first and third fiscal quarterly filed statutory financial        statements, respectively, subject to any adjustments or modifications        thereto required by the Domiciliary State's insurance department or the        Company's independent auditors) falls below the Specified Minimum        Percentage of the Company's projected Company Action Level RBC (in each        case as estimated by the Company as of the end of each such first and        third fiscal quarters, as the case may be), AIG shall, within the        respective time periods set forth under paragraph 4, in accordance with        paragraph 5 and in compliance with applicable law, provide to the        Company cash, cash equivalents, securities or other instruments that        qualify (as admitted assets) for purposes of calculating the Company's        Total Adjusted Capital, as a contribution and not as a loan, in an        amount such that the Company's Total Adjusted Capital as of the end of        each of the
perturbation.explanation: Using both "Insurer" and "Company" without explicitly defining them as interchangeable, creates confusion. It is unclear if calculations from the Insurer should be measured against the Company's financial activities.

perturbation.original_text: Notwithstanding the obligation of the Company and AIG to review the Specified Minimum        Percentage on an annual basis, the parties hereto agree to review and        revise the Specified Minimum Percentage on a more frequent basis, if the        parties agree it is appropriate, to take into account (a) any material        changes after the date hereof to any Agency Criteria adopted by any of        S&P, Moody's or A.M. Best, on the one hand, or to the law of the        Domiciliary State or NAIC RBC rules or instructions, on the other hand,        which causes the results under the Agency Criteria to diverge from that        under the law of the Domiciliary State or NAIC RBC rules or        instructions, (b) the Company completes a material transaction that is        treated materially differently by the Agency Criteria, on the one hand,        and the NAIC RBC rules or instructions, on the other hand, or (c) any        other material development or circumstance affecting the Company which        AIG and the Company agree merits a reevaluation of the Specified Minimum        Percentage then in effect.
perturbation.changed_text: Notwithstanding the obligation of the Insurer and AIG to review the Specified Minimum        Percentage on an annual basis, the parties hereto agree to review and        revise the Specified Minimum Percentage on a more frequent basis, if the        parties agree it is appropriate, to take into account (a) any material        changes after the date hereof to any Agency Criteria adopted by any of        S&P, Moody's or A.M. Best, on the one hand, or to the law of the        Domiciliary State or NAIC RBC rules or instructions, on the other hand,        which causes the results under the Agency Criteria to diverge from that        under the law of the Domiciliary State or NAIC RBC rules or        instructions, (b) the Company completes a material transaction that is        treated materially differently by the Agency Criteria, on the one hand,        and the NAIC RBC rules or instructions, on the other hand, or (c) any        other material development or circumstance affecting the Insurer which        AIG and the Insurer agree merits a reevaluation of the Specified Minimum        Percentage then in effect.
perturbation.explanation: The inconsistent switching between 'Company' and 'Insurer' in this paragraph (3) makes it unclear whether the obligations and considerations apply equally to both entities. If 'Insurer' and 'Company' are not the same, then the review obligations become ambiguous, impacting the enforceability of capital maintenance.
